Thanks Cris, I was hoping that I would not have to do that, but 
sometimes there are no easy solution. For right now I decided to 
factor out the code as a fixture.

Thanks again,

Zoran

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Chris Morris <chrismo@c...> wrote:
> zoran_101 wrote:
> 
> >Thanks, this helped a lot, and also I happen to have the JUnit 
> >Recepies book so I just looked it up. However it looks like that 
I 
> >will have to run my tests in a container, meaning I have to use 
> >Cactus. I don't think I can do this with Cactus because they 
> >instantiate TestCase. If there is a way I would love to know.
> >  
> >
> Another less elegant solution is to simply do your own comparison 
> instead of the assertEquals, store any failures in an Array or 
somesuch, 
> then, at the end of the whole loop,  assertEquals that the problem 
array 
> is empty, dumping the contents of the array into the message param.
> 
> -- 
> Chris
> http://clabs.org
